msgSnippet: ... Warning!  the assert keyword may _not_ be evaluated.  Sun sugests to run the Java application without the assert option to increase speed.  So you cannot
messageBody:
> the assert:
> - can not be ignored (exception can be ignored via emtpy try catch
> block)


Warning! the assert keyword may _not_ be evaluated. Sun sugests to run
the Java application without the "assert" option to increase speed. So
you cannot be sure that your application will _always_ run in the
'assert' mode. Using the _optional_ 'assert' mode to validate something
that is _not_ optional (parameter's value) is IMO a big mistake.

> the exception:
> - is more explicit (IllegalArgument tells me the exact problem)
> - better communicated in docs (javadoc picks it up, hopefully this
> will change for assertions one day)


if (n < 0)
throw new IllegalArgumentException("blah");

if (n < 0) the exception will _always_ be thrown


> But at the end of the day they the look the same to me - just
> different in implementation.


absolutely not, because at the end of the day you can run your program
without evaluating the assert keyword and you don't control anything
anymore. This is a _big_ difference.

My point is that an _optional_ assertion mechanism ("assert" keyword)
cannot replace a _non-optional_ error-reporting mechanism (exceptions).
They may be complementary (still not convinced by 'assert').

Or am I missing the point?

-Vladimir
